title: St Pancras station evacuated and trains cancelled due to ’emergency’
text:
Crowds outside St Pancras International station after it was evacuated (Picture: Twitter)

Train passengers were evacuated from St Pancras International train station in central London this afternoon after loudspeakers warned ‘this is an emergency’.

Several rail companies then tweeted to announce that services in and out of the station were cancelled.

Pictures and video showed people crowding on pavements outside St Pancras and its adjoining King’s Cross Underground station.

Southeastern Rail said no services were leaving or arriving at the international train station while Thameslink tweeted that its trains would not be calling at the station ‘until further notice’.

A spokesperson Govia Thameslink Railway later said the ’emergency’ was caused by a fire alarm being set off at around 1pm.

British Transport Police confirmed the incident was related to the fire alarm.

A spokeswoman said the station was given the all clear at around 1.45pm and services are resuming.

Some delays to train services are expected until around 3pm.

St Pancras International station serves areas in the east of England, including Cambridgeshire, Northamptonshire, Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire.

It also serves areas in southeastern England and runs trains from London to Paris on the Eurostar.
